context: <a8_0>From <a0_0><a5_0>1842<a5_0/><a0_0/> onwards<a8_0/>, Chopin showed signs of serious illness. After a solo recital in Paris on 21 February 1842, he wrote to <a1_0>Grzymała<a1_0/>: "I have to lie in bed all day long, my <a9_0>mouth and tonsils<a9_0/> are aching so much." He was forced by illness to decline a written invitation from <a10_0>Alkan<a10_0/> to participate in a repeat performance of the <a2_0><a6_0>Beethoven Seventh Symphony arrangement<a6_0/> at Erard's<a2_0/> on 1 March 1843. Late in 1844, <a11_0>Charles Hallé<a11_0/> visited Chopin and found him "hardly able to move, bent like a half-opened penknife and evidently in great pain", although his spirits returned when he started to play the <a3_0>piano<a3_0/> for his visitor. Chopin's health continued to deteriorate, particularly from this time onwards. Modern research suggests that apart from any other illnesses, he may also have suffered from <a4_0><a7_0><a12_0>temporal lobe epilepsy<a7_0/><a4_0/>.
